message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: A Survey of Autonomous Underwater Vehicle Formation: Performance, Formation Control, and Communication Capability
Paper Abstract: Autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) are submersible underwater vehicles controlled by onboard computers. AUV formation is a cooperative control which focuses on controlling multiple AUVs to move in a group while executing tasks. In contrast to a single AUV, multi-AUV formation represents higher efficiency and better stability for many applications, such as oil and gas industries, hydrographic surveys, and military missions, etc. To achieve better formation, there are several key factors, including AUV performance, formation control, and communication capability. However, most studies in the field of AUV formation mainly focus on formation control methods. We observe that the research of communication capability and AUV performance of multiple AUV formation is still in an early stage. It is beneficial to researchers to present a comprehensive survey of the state of the art of AUV formation research and development. In this paper, we study AUV, formation control, and underwater acoustic communication capability in detail. We propose a classification framework with three dimensions, including AUV performance, formation control, and communication capability. This framework provides a comprehensive classification method for future AUV formation research. It also can be used to compare different methods and help engineers choose suitable formation methods for various applications. Moreover, our survey discusses formation architecture with communication constraints and we identify some common misconceptions and questionable research for formation control related to communication.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the web search results, "Cooperative control" can refer to several different concepts depending on the context:

## Technology & Systems Context

In systems design, collaborative control enables all entities involved in a decentralized system to share their resources, information, and responsibilities, such that mutual benefits are obtained and sustained.(no content)In automotive technology, Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control (CACC) is an extension to adaptive cruise control using Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) communication that realizes longitudinal automated vehicle control.

## Business & Economics Context

In a business sense, cooperative control refers to how cooperatives operate. Co-operatives are autonomous, self-help organizations controlled by their members, and if they enter into agreements with other organizations, they do so on terms that ensure democratic control by their members and maintain their co-operative autonomy.(no content)Democratic member control is a key Rochdale Principle for co-operative societies, with co-operatives being democratic organizations controlled by their members who actively participate in setting their policies, where in primary co-operatives members have equal voting rights (one member, one vote).

The specific meaning of "cooperative control" depends on whether you're discussing systems engineering, vehicle automation, or organizational governance.

I performed a web search for "Formation control" and got results covering several different topics. Here are the main findings:

## Formation Control in Robotics

Formation control of robotic systems is a research area within the field of robotics, particularly studied by researchers like M. Anthony Lewis who work on evolutionary and biomorphic robotics.

## Other Meanings

The search results also returned several unrelated topics that share similar terminology:

- **Oil Well Control**: Oil well control involves preventing formation gas or fluid (hydrocarbons) from entering into the wellbore during drilling or well interventions.

- **Control Theory**: Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems, aiming to develop models or algorithms to drive systems to a desired state.

If you're looking for more specific information about formation control in a particular context (such as multi-agent systems, UAVs, swarm robotics, etc.), please let me know and I can search for more targeted results.

## Search Results for "Autonomous underwater vehicle"

Here's what I found about autonomous underwater vehicles:

### Definition and Overview
An autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) is a robot that travels underwater without requiring continuous input from an operator.(no content)AUVs constitute part of a larger group of undersea systems known as unmanned underwater vehicles, which includes non-autonomous remotely operated underwater vehicles (ROVs) – controlled and powered from the surface by an operator via an umbilical or using remote control.

### History
The first AUV was developed at the Applied Physics Laboratory at the University of Washington as early as 1957 by Stan Murphy, Bob Francois and later on, Terry Ewart. The "Self-Propelled Underwater Research Vehicle", or SPURV, was used to study diffusion, acoustic transmission, and submarine wakes.

### Technology and Navigation
AUVs carry sensors to navigate autonomously and map features of the ocean. Typical sensors include compasses, depth sensors, sidescan and other sonars, magnetometers, thermistors and conductivity probes.(no content)Radio waves cannot penetrate water very far, so as soon as an AUV dives it loses its GPS signal. Therefore, a standard way for AUVs to navigate underwater is through dead reckoning.

### Power Systems
Most AUVs in use today are powered by rechargeable batteries (lithium ion, lithium polymer, nickel metal hydride etc.), and are implemented with some form of battery management system.

### Applications
AUVs have been used to find wreckage of missing airplanes, such as Air France Flight 447, and the Bluefin-21 AUV was used in the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

Here are the search results for "Hydrographic survey":

## Definition and Purpose

Hydrographic survey is the science of measurement and description of features which affect maritime navigation, marine construction, dredging, offshore wind farms, offshore oil exploration and drilling and related activities.(no content)Strong emphasis is placed on soundings, shorelines, tides, currents, seabed and submerged obstructions that relate to the previously mentioned activities.

## Key Focus Areas

A hydrographic survey may include the accurate positions and representations of hills, mountains and even lights and towers that will aid in fixing a ship's position, as well as the physical aspects of the sea and seabed. Additionally, surveys may also be conducted to determine the route of subsea cables such as telecommunications cables, cables associated with wind farms, and HVDC power cables.

## Historical Methods and Modern Approaches

For many centuries, a hydrographic survey required the use of lead lines – ropes or lines with depth markings attached to lead weights to make one end sink to the bottom when lowered over the side of a ship or boat – and sounding poles, which were poles with depth markings which could be thrust over the side until they touched bottom. Modern surveys now utilize more advanced technology for improved accuracy and efficiency.

## Organizational Structure

Hydrographic offices evolved from naval heritage and are usually found within national naval structures. Coordination of those organizations and product standardization is voluntarily joined with the goal of improving hydrography and safe navigation and is conducted by the International Hydrographic Organization (IHO).

Web search results for query: "Underwater acoustic communication"

Links: [{"title":"Underwater acoustic communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Underwater_acoustic_communication"},{"title":"Underwater acoustics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Underwater_acoustics"},{"title":"Acoustic communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acoustic_communication"},{"title":"Christine Erbe - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christine_Erbe"},{"title":"Milica Stojanovic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milica_Stojanovic"},{"title":"Pioneers of Underwater Acoustics Medal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pioneers_of_Underwater_Acoustics_Medal"}]

## Underwater Acoustic Communication

Underwater acoustic communication is a technique of sending and receiving messages in water.(no content)The most common method employs hydrophones.

### Key Challenges

Underwater communication is difficult due to factors such as multi-path propagation, time variations of the channel, small available bandwidth and strong signal attenuation, especially over long ranges.(no content)Compared to terrestrial communication, underwater communication has low data rates because it uses acoustic waves instead of electromagnetic waves.

### Modulation Methods

Modulation methods developed for radio communications can be adapted for underwater acoustic communications, though some schemes are more suited to the unique underwater acoustic communication channel than others. Common techniques include:

- **FSK (Frequency Shift Keying)**: FSK is the earliest form of modulation used for acoustic modems.
- **OFDM**: OFDM is a favorable communication scheme in underwater acoustic communications thanks to its resilience against frequency selective channels with long delay spreads.
- **Continuous Phase Modulation (CPM)**: CPM is a modulation technique with continuous phase shift where the phase of the carrier signal varies over time and avoids abrupt changes between successive symbols. This smooth phase trajectory reduces spectral side lobes and increases the spectral efficiency of CPM.

### Applications and Standards

The underwater telephone, also known as UQC, AN/WQC-2, or Gertrude, was used by the U.S. Navy in 1945.(no content)In April 2017, NATO's Centre for Maritime Research and Experimentation announced the approval of JANUS, a standardized protocol to transmit digital information underwater using acoustic sound, documented in STANAG 4748, which uses 900 Hz to 60 kHz frequencies at distances of up to 28 kilometres.

Underwater communication is difficult due to factors such as multi-path propagation, time variations of the channel, small available bandwidth and strong signal attenuation, especially over long ranges.(no content)Compared to terrestrial communication, underwater communication has low data rates because it uses acoustic waves instead of electromagnetic waves.

### Modulation Methods

Modulation methods developed for radio communications can be adapted for underwater acoustic communications, though some schemes are more suited to the unique underwater acoustic communication channel than others. Common techniques include:

- **FSK (Frequency Shift Keying)**: FSK is the earliest form of modulation used for acoustic modems.
- **OFDM**: OFDM is a favorable communication scheme in underwater acoustic communications thanks to its resilience against frequency selective channels with long delay spreads.
- **Continuous Phase Modulation (CPM)**: CPM is a modulation technique with continuous phase shift where the phase of the carrier signal varies over time and avoids abrupt changes between successive symbols. This smooth phase trajectory reduces spectral side lobes and increases the spectral efficiency of CPM.

### Applications and Standards

The underwater telephone, also known as UQC, AN/WQC-2, or Gertrude, was used by the U.S. Navy in 1945.(no content)In April 2017, NATO's Centre for Maritime Research and Experimentation announced the approval of JANUS, a standardized protocol to transmit digital information underwater using acoustic sound, documented in STANAG 4748, which uses 900 Hz to 60 kHz frequencies at distances of up to 28 kilometres.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about multi-agent system robotics:

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)The agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.

## Key Capabilities

Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve. In robotics specifically, multi-agent systems present possible applications in microrobotics, where the physical interaction between the agents are exploited to perform complex tasks such as manipulation and assembly of passive components.

## Research Applications

Biologically-inspired multi-agent systems research includes collective algorithms, programming paradigms, modular and swarm robotics, studying bio-inspired algorithms, programming paradigms, and hardware designs for swarm/modular robotic systems, drawing inspiration mainly from social insects and multicellular biology.(no content)Research in multi-agent systems includes applications to tasks such as cooperative transportation, robotic formations, cooperative search/rescue, and odor source localization.

## Challenges

Issues with multi-agent systems include few coordination protocols between component agents, inconsistent performance, and challenges debugging.

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Perceptual control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptual_control_theory"},{"title":"Social control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_control_theory"},{"title":"Control theory (sociology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory_(sociology)"},{"title":"Affect control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_control_theory"},{"title":"Closed system (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed_system_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"},{"title":"Compensator (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compensator_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"}]

Here are the search results for "Control theory":

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actualand desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## History

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)Although the most direct application of mathematical control theory is its use in control systems engineering, control theory is routinely applied to problems both the natural and behavioral sciences. As the general theory of feedback systems, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "A Survey of Autonomous Underwater Vehicle Formation: Performance, Formation Control, and Communication Capability". Here's a summary of what was done:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey

**Triples Identified and Validated (5 total):**

1. **Autonomous underwater vehicle** (artifact) - Core subject of the survey covering submersible vehicles controlled by onboard computers
2. **Control theory** (concept) - Theoretical foundation for formation control methods
3. **Underwater acoustic communication** (method) - Critical communication capability for coordinating AUV formations
4. **Multi-agent system** (concept) - Conceptual framework for cooperative control of multiple AUVs
5. **Hydrographic survey** (task) - Key application domain for multi-AUV formations

All triples have been properly documented in `triples_output.json` with:
- Correct Wikipedia URLs (verified)
- Appropriate entity types
- "uses" relation (as this is a survey paper reviewing existing work)
- Clear relevance statements

The validation script confirms all requirements are met with no errors.

Sources:
- [Autonomous underwater vehicle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_underwater_vehicle)
- [Control theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory)
- [Underwater acoustic communication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Underwater_acoustic_communication)
- [Multi-agent system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system)
- [Hydrographic survey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrographic_survey)
